captions.text:
I-I have to cut the rope!
I'm sorry!

- There's too much weight!
It has to be done! I'm sorry!

What makes you think HE
can hold YOU?!

- Trust me! He can!
He's been working out!

Tell him I've been
working out!

- Well, if anything,
can't we cut the piano off?

- Hmm. Yeah, that might actually
be a good place to start.

I didn't come all the way to
perform the 1st Sonata

on the summit of this mountain
just to fall off and die!

I'm sorry!
There's no other way!
The piano is just too heavy.

Seriously though!
We're all gonna die!

Hold on! We're gonna
figure this out!

- If I may, uh, if you're still
deciding that whole

where to cut the rope thing, um,
pretty sure the guy below me
- I'm a teacher, not a pedofile!
I told you guys like nine times.

- Not just that,
they're retarded kids!

- Hey, uh, can't we just cut off
the Panda Bear?

- Oh, okay.
What does everyone else think?

It's been an honor
climbing with you guys!

I'll see you all
in another life!

comments.author: Michael Meissner

comments.text:
+Emi Loli
But it's not a mistake. It's still properly punctuated. It may *look* 
better (in your opinion) with a semicolon or as separate sentences, but it 
is not improper to use a comma. If those were two unrelated sentences, I 
would separate them as two sentences. If they were one sentence, followed 
by a somewhat related sentence, I would separate them with a semicolon. But 
because they exist as one sentence followed by a directly corresponding 
response, I chose to separate them with a comma.

And as for the looks, using a semicolon where anything else would be just 
as proper only serves to make one look like a pretentious prick. Even my 
English teacher agrees with me.
comments.author: Michael Meissner

comments.text:
+Michael Meissner Although I am not part of this conversation, I will 
correct you so you may edit your reply and whatnot. "Don't tell me that I 
am making errors, tell me what errors I am making" would look much better 
being separate sentences. Or if not that, separated with a semicolon.
comments.author: Emi Loli

comments.text:
+Michael Meissner Although I am not part of this conversation, I will 
correct you so you may edit your reply and whatnot. "Don't tell me that I 
am making errors, tell me what errors I am making" would look much better 
being separate sentences. Or if not that, separated with a semicolon.
comments.author: Emi Loli

comments.text:
+balkoth1984
Don't tell me that I am making errors, tell me what errors I am making.


Regardless, you made a mistake in your own sentence. A comma should follow 
"Actually".
comments.author: Michael Meissner

comments.text:
+Michael Meissner Actually you're making many mistakes, especially with 
commas.
comments.author: balkoth1984

comments.text:
+CompassRose
I'm a Grammar Nazi, not a Quote Nazi. I make no mistakes in my grammar, but 
my hearing is another matter, it seems. Besides, my misquoting comment is 
still very close to the actual quote, and with no change in the syntax or 
meaning of the quote, is still funny. There is no irony here, only assholes.
comments.author: Michael Meissner

comments.text:
+Michael Meissner In their defense, you have the badge of a grammar nazi, 
so making a big deal out of small mistakes that don't detract from the 
overall meaning is kind of what you do. This is kind of ironic.
comments.author: CompassRose

comments.text:
+salvador terrence elizalde
Oh, look, Explosm-given subtitles, which were not there when I first made 
the comment. Okay, so I was wrong. I've noted that before. My point that 
slightly misquoting does not make me a dumbass and doesn't detract from the 
comedic value still stands.
